questions.question: The sun rises in the east _ sets in the west.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'and' is used to connect two related actions.

questions.question: He studied hard, _ he passed the exam.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'so' indicates a result of studying hard.

questions.question: She is not only smart _ also very kind.
questions.explanation: The correlative conjunction 'not only...but also' is used to add emphasis to both qualities.

questions.question: You can have cake _ ice cream for dessert.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'or' is used to present a choice between two options.

questions.question: He was tired, _ he went to bed early.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'so' indicates a result of being tired.

questions.question: I will wait here _ you finish your work.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'until' indicates the time up to which the action of waiting will continue.

questions.question: She talks _ she knows everything.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'as if' is used to describe a manner that is not true.

questions.question: You can go out to play _ you finish your homework.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'if' introduces a condition for going out to play.

questions.question: _ he was late, he still managed to catch the bus.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'although' is used to show a contrast between being late and catching the bus.

questions.question: She is both intelligent _ hardworking.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'and' is used to add two positive qualities.

questions.question: He is rich _ unhappy.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'but' is used to show a contrast between being rich and unhappy.

questions.question: I will call you _ I arrive.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'when' indicates the time of calling.

questions.question: She sings _ she plays the piano.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'and' is used to connect two related actions.

questions.question: He is not only a good teacher _ also a great mentor.
questions.explanation: The correlative conjunction 'not only...but also' is used to add emphasis to both qualities.

questions.question: You can take the bus _ the train to get there.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'or' is used to present a choice between two options.

questions.question: He was hungry, _ he ate a sandwich.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'so' indicates a result of being hungry.

questions.question: I will stay here _ you come back.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'until' indicates the time up to which the action of staying will continue.

questions.question: She behaves _ she owns the place.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'as if' is used to describe a manner that is not true.

questions.question: You can go out _ you finish your chores.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'if' introduces a condition for going out.

questions.question: _ it was raining, they went for a walk.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'although' is used to show a contrast between raining and going for a walk.

questions.question: She is both talented _ hardworking.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'and' is used to add two positive qualities.

questions.question: He is poor _ honest.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'but' is used to show a contrast between being poor and honest.

questions.question: I will visit you _ I have time.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'when' indicates the time of visiting.

questions.question: She dances _ she sings.
questions.explanation: The conjunction 'and' is used to connect two related actions.

questions.question: He is not only a good friend _ also a great advisor.
questions.explanation: The correlative conjunction 'not only...but also' is used to add emphasis to both qualities.
